Explanations about Options.-i:
Listen on interface. If unspecified, tcpdump searches the system interface list
 for the lowest numbered, configured up interface (excluding loopback), which may
 turn out to be, for example, ``eth0''.

Answers.MP Summary: Print  network  connections,  routing tables, interface statistics, masquerade connections, and multicast memberships

su_1548679: netstat -anltp | grep "LISTEN" 
(Not all processes could be identified, non-owned process info
 will not be shown, you would have to be root to see it all.)
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.1:8080          0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      2446/node           
tcp        0      0 127.0.0.53:53           0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      -                   
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:22              0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN      -                   
tcp6       0      0 :::22                   :::*                    LISTEN      -

Explanations about Options.-a:
Show both listening and non-listening sockets. With the --interfaces option, show
 interfaces that are not up
Explanations about Options.-p: Show the PID and name of the program to which each socket belongs.
Explanations about Options.-l: Show only listening sockets. (These are omitted by default.)
Explanations about Options.-n: Show numerical addresses instead of trying to determine symbolic host, port or user names.

ul_344521: hafw1:~# ss -tapn | grep ":22"
LISTEN     0      128            :::22                      :::*      users:(("sshd",9828,4))
LISTEN     0      128             *:22                       *:*      users:(("sshd",9828,3))
ESTAB      0      0  my_ip:59233        dest:22     users:(("ssh",1625,3))

watch -n 1  ss -tapn \| grep ":554"

Explanations about Options.-a:
Display both listening and non-listening (for TCP this means established
 connections) sockets.
Explanations about Options.-n:
Do not try to resolve service names. Show exact bandwidth values, instead of human-
 readable.
